channel.title: NYT > Arts > Music
channel.copyright: Copyright 2025 The New York Times Company

item.title: The Met Opera’s Leaner ‘Magic Flute’ Courts Young Listeners
item.description: Julie Taymor’s abridged production of Mozart’s opera has been trimmed down to 90 minutes as the Metropolitan Opera bids to recruit a new generation.
item.dc:creator: Adam Nagourney and Rachel Sherman
item.media:credit: Amir Hamja for The New York Times
item.media:description: A student from P.S. 131 takes in the opera. The biggest applause of the afternoon came when Papageno managed to smuggle in a “6-7.”

item.title: Romeo Santos and Prince Royce Want Bachata to Share in Latin Music’s Boom
item.description: Despite huge collaborations, top-selling albums and sellout tours, the leading stars of the Dominican genre still feel like they haven’t received their due.
item.dc:creator: Jon Caramanica and Joe Coscarelli
item.media:credit: Victor Llorente for The New York Times
item.media:description: In November, Santos and Royce — who had never before collaborated — released “Better Late Than Never,” a joint album. Next year, they’ll tour together.

item.title: Gen Z’s Pop Breakouts Danced in Britney Spears’s Footsteps in 2025
item.description: Sabrina Carpenter, Tate McRae and Addison Rae’s music is influenced by the superstar who shot to fame before they were born. They’ve learned lessons from her hard times, too.
item.dc:creator: Lindsay Zoladz
item.media:credit: Daniel Zuchnik/Getty Images; Mike Coppola/Getty Images; Scott Gries/Getty Images; Matt Winkelmeyer/Getty Images

item.title: Best Classical Music Albums of 2025
item.description: Listen to recordings by Maria Dueñas and Daniil Trifonov, works by Thomas Adès and Tania León, and more.
item.media:credit: From top: Balarama Heller for The New York Times; Amir Hamja/The New York Times; Tom Jamieson for The New York Times
item.media:description: From top, Meredith Monk, Alice Sara Ott, Samson Tsoy and Pavel Kolesnikov: several of the artists behind the best classical music albums of the year.

item.title: Rafael Ithier, Ambassador of Puerto Rican Music, Dies at 99
item.description: Leading the acclaimed salsa group El Gran Combo de Puerto Rico, he brought the music of his native island to a worldwide audience for more than 60 years.
item.dc:creator: Alex Williams
item.category: El Gran Combo de Puerto Rico

item.title: Jelly Roll Is Pardoned for Previous Robbery and Drug Convictions
item.description: The clemency decision by Gov. Bill Lee of Tennessee could make it easier for the country star to travel internationally.
item.dc:creator: Emmanuel Morgan
item.media:description: Jelly Roll was found guilty of participating in an armed robbery in 2002. In another case, the police found cocaine and marijuana in his car.

item.title: ‘Counting Crows: Have You Seen Me Lately?’ Review: Becoming Big Stars
item.description: The band became a major success in 1993 with the hit “Mr. Jones.” Since then, the group has done its best to keep rock music alive.
item.dc:creator: Glenn Kenny
item.category: Counting Crows: Have You Seen Me Lately? (Movie)

item.title: An Infamous Australian Prison Held the Unexpected: A Record Collection
item.description: Pentridge Prison’s radio station played donated albums for its inmates. Twenty-six years after the site’s sale, a local shop has landed its vinyl.
item.dc:creator: RM Clark

item.title: John Darnielle on His Favorite Books and Annotated Lyrics
item.description: The novelist and musician is a voracious reader of books in translation. In “This Year,” he annotates the literary lyrics to 365 of his own songs.
item.category: This Year: 365 Songs Annotated: A Book of Days (Book)

item.title: The Most Magical, Moving Four Minutes in Music
item.description: Ravel’s depiction of an enchanted garden is so simple and wistful, I never want it to end.
item.dc:creator: David Allen

item.title: How Track Star Became a YouTube and TikTok Music Phenomenon
item.description: “Track Star” is the YouTube series that brings out the music lover in celebrities and civilians alike.
item.dc:creator: Jessica M. Goldstein
item.media:credit: Peter Fisher for The New York Times
item.media:description: Jack Coyne, the host of the popular online show “Track Star,” quizzes people on identifying songs.

item.title: Hear the Best Albums and Songs of 2025
item.description: 90 tracks! Five hours! Remix the year in pop however you wish.
item.dc:creator: Lindsay Zoladz
item.media:description: Bad Bunny made both Jon Caramanica and Lindsay Zoladz’s lists of the year’s best albums.

item.title: Bristow: A Founding Father of the American Symphony
item.description: George Frederick Bristow, born 200 years ago this month, struggled to find American champions of his music as orchestras favored European tradition.
item.dc:creator: Douglas W. Shadle
item.media:credit: Heritage Art/Heritage Images, via Getty Images
item.media:description: George Frederick Bristow, an American composer who admired the European tradition of classical music and wrote within it.

item.title: ‘Beaches’ Was a Novel. Then a Movie. Next, It’ll Be a Broadway Musical.
item.description: A musical adaptation of the story will open at the Majestic Theater next spring. And yes, the score includes “Wind Beneath My Wings.”
item.dc:creator: Michael Paulson
item.media:description: Jessica Vosk, left, and Kelli Barrett starred in a production of “Beaches” last year at Theater Calgary in Canada, and will do so again next year on Broadway.

item.title: A Pipe Organist Invites You to Bliss Out to Her Dreamy Colors
item.description: Ellen Arkbro makes music that shifts and churns with scant regard for harmonic convention. She’s one of the most interesting composers for her instrument working today.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Dickson and Gordon Welters

item.title: Joe Ely, Texas-Born Troubadour of the Open Road, Dies at 78
item.description: Thanks to his eclectic style and tireless touring, he was among the most influential artists in the early days of Americana and alt-country music.
item.dc:creator: Clay Risen
item.media:description: Joe Ely in 1981. He wrote songs about lost love and endless vistas, built around stories of everyday people leading everyday lives.

item.title: ‘Titaníque,’ Singing and Spoofing Celine Dion, Sets Sail for Broadway
item.description: This zany musical made it from the basement of a Manhattan grocery to London’s West End, and now hopes to become Broadway’s next hit comedy.
item.dc:creator: Michael Paulson
item.media:credit: Evelyn Freja for The New York Times
item.media:description: The “Titaníque” team includes, from top to bottom, the director Tye Blue, the writer Constantine Rousouli, the actor Marla Mindelle and the music supervisor Nicholas James Connell.

item.title: 11 New Holiday Albums That Will Make You Gasp, Laugh and Sway
item.description: Fresh entries into the tradition include releases by Luke Bryan, Tyra Banks and Old Crow Medicine Show.
item.dc:creator: Jon Caramanica, Jon Pareles and Lindsay Zoladz

item.title: ‘A Christmas Carol’, ‘Dead Outlaw’ and More Theater to Stream
item.description: Other picks include a family production of “The Snow Queen,” the Broadway-bound “Every Brilliant Thing” and the acclaimed comedy “Sorry for Your Loss.”
item.dc:creator: Rachel Sherman

item.title: Olivia Dean, Josh Johnson and Chase Infiniti Are Among Our 2025 Breakout Stars
item.description: Across the arts, these 10 performers took a leap of faith this year and stuck the landing in a big way.
item.dc:creator: Maya Salam

item.title: Berg’s ‘Wozzeck’ Keeps Shocking Us, After 100 Years
item.description: Alban Berg’s “Wozzeck,” which premiered in the shadow of World War I, will break your heart with a score that captures the essence of opera.
item.dc:creator: Joshua Barone

item.title: Abraham Quintanilla Jr., 86, Dies; Music Producer Steered Daughter Selena’s Career
item.description: As a teenager, he hoped to make it big in the Tejano music world. He realized that dream through his daughter.
item.dc:creator: Jesus Jiménez
item.media:description: Abraham Quintanilla Jr. in 2005. With his daughter Selena doing vocals, he turned his small family band into a Grammy-winning act, and Selena became known as the queen of Tejano music.

item.title: 41 Things That Stuck With Us in 2025
item.description: Aunt Gladys. Tyler, the Creator. That sex scene in “The Naked Gun.” These are the things Culture staffers couldn’t stop thinking about this year.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.category: The Real Housewives of Orange County (TV Program)
item.media:credit: Neon; Sara Krulwich/The New York Times; Daniel Arnold, via Loose Joints; Warner Bros.

item.title: Hanukkah Concerts With Israeli Military Cantor Raise Outcry in Amsterdam
item.description: A concert hall canceled the performance several months ago but then reached a compromise in which three concerts will be held. The bargain hasn’t satisfied critics of the events.
item.dc:creator: Nina Siegal
item.media:description: Shai Abramson, the chief cantor for the Israeli military, singing in Budapest in January.

item.title: Slick Rick Likes His Tea ‘Strong and British’
item.description: “It’s the English side of me that never dies,” said the pioneering wordsmith who is celebrating 40 years of hip-hop classics like “La-Di-Da-Di.”
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Abrams
